page.title: 01Chwilog and District West
page.content: This is an agricultural district of small grassland fields, devotted to grazing sheep and beef catle and to a lesser extent, milk production tourism is strong, secondary industry. Butlins Holiday Centre, ocupying much of the headland of Pen-Y-Chain, services some 130,000 guests per season additionally, most farmers profit from the tourist 'crop'. Whilst there is virtually no arable land the landscape is busy with trees and shurubs, maily scrub-oak, sycamore, ash, gorse and broom. The climate is typical of west Wales, dominated by the prevailing South-Westerlies and whilst wetter than average, exhibits mildwinters. The one village, Chwilog, straddles the toll road to Porthdinllaen and possesses the only pub in the district. On a minor road from the
